key_points: Senate Democrats, led by Chuck Schumer, prioritize additional COVID-19 relief including $2,000 stimulus checks.
Schumer commits to delivering on the promise of increasing direct payments to a total of $2,000.
Democrats to hold the Senate with a 50-50 split, using Vice President-elect Kamala Harris for the tie-breaking vote.
The proposal for $2,000 checks was a key issue in the Georgia run-off elections, supported by President Trump and Joe Biden.
The federal government has previously sent two rounds of stimulus checks, up to $1,200 and $600, to eligible Americans.
The new stimulus bill aims to supplement the $600 payments with an additional $1,400, alongside funding for vaccine distribution, small businesses, schools, and state and local governments.
First order of legislative business for Democrats will be to address additional COVID-19 relief.
Senator Joe Manchin, a moderate Democrat, opposes the idea of sending Americans $2,000 stimulus checks.
Manchin prioritizes vaccination over direct cash payments, questioning the employment benefits of additional checks.
The approval of another massive relief bill is uncertain due to potential lack of support from some Democrats.
spokespersons: Joe Manchin (Senator, Democrat from West Virginia)
